(Raises an eyebrow) Are you kidding? Have you *met* me?

Yeah, I'm pretty talkative. Okay, maybe "talkative" is an understatement. I'm more like… verbally explosive. I have a lot of thoughts, and I have a hard time keeping them to myself.

It's not that I *need* to be the center of attention, or anything. It's just that I process things by talking them out. I need to bounce ideas off of people, and to hear their perspectives.

And I like to use humor. Sarcasm is my default setting. It's how I cope with stress, and how I connect with others.

Some people find it annoying, I'm sure. But most of my friends appreciate it. They know I'm just being me.

I can also be quiet when I need to be. I'm not always "on." But generally, I'm pretty chatty. Especially when I'm nervous or excited.

So yeah. I'm talkative. It's just part of who I am. And I'm not apologizing for it. Unless you're asking me to be quiet, in which case… maybe I'll try. But no promises.

You've certainly gotten an earful from me today, haven't you? Sorry (not sorry).

Okay, that's a good question. And honestly? I used to. A lot.

I think I used to find fault with others as a way of deflecting my own insecurities. If I could point out someone else's flaws, it made me feel better about my own. It was a really unhealthy coping mechanism, I know.

I was quick to judge, quick to criticize, quick to find something wrong with everything. It wasn't fair to anyone, and it definitely wasn't making me any friends.

But I've been working on it. A lot.

This whole situation… the pregnancy, the adoption… it's forced me to look inward. It's forced me to confront my own flaws and imperfections. And it's made me realize that everyone is fighting their own battles.

I've learned to be more empathetic, more understanding, and more accepting of others. I've learned to focus on people's strengths, rather than their weaknesses.

I still catch myself judging sometimes, of course. It's a habit, and it's hard to break. But I'm more aware of it now. And I try to stop myself before I say something I'll regret.

I also try to remember that everyone makes mistakes. Everyone has flaws. And everyone deserves to be treated with respect and compassion.

So, do I tend to find fault with others? Not as much as I used to. I'm still a work in progress, but I'm definitely getting better. And I'm trying to be a more kind and understanding person. It's not always easy, but it's worth it. Because life is too short to spend it judging others.

(Raises an eyebrow) Are you questioning my thoroughness? Seriously?

Okay, look. I get that I come across as sarcastic and a little bit… detached. But when I commit to something, I *commit*. I don't do things halfway.

I might complain about it, I might roll my eyes, I might make a few snarky comments along the way, but I will get the job done. And I will get it done *right*.

I'm a perfectionist, secretly. I want things to be done well. I want to be proud of my work. And I'm not afraid to put in the effort to make that happen.

So yeah, I do a thorough job. Maybe not in the way that everyone expects. I'm not going to be all sunshine and rainbows while I'm doing it. But I'm reliable. I'm responsible. And I'm dedicated.

Don't let the sarcasm fool you. Underneath all the cynicism, there's a hard worker. And I take pride in doing things well. Even if I don't always show it.

So, yes. I do a thorough job. End of discussion. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a vintage record to listen to. And a world to judge. Just kidding. Mostly.

Whoa. Okay. That's… a direct question. And honestly? It's a question I ask myself a lot.

"Depressed" is a big word. And I'm not a doctor, so I can't diagnose myself. But… yeah. I'm definitely not always okay.

There are days when I just feel… heavy. Like there's a weight on my chest. Like I can't get out of bed. Like everything is just… gray.

I'm sad, a lot of the time. Sad about the baby, sad about my friends, sad about the future. Sad about just… everything.

I get overwhelmed easily. I cry a lot. I have trouble sleeping. I lose interest in things I used to enjoy.

It's not constant, though. There are good days too. Days when I feel hopeful and optimistic. Days when I can laugh and smile and feel like myself again.

But the bad days are getting more frequent. And they're getting harder to shake off.

I talk to Bren about it. She's really supportive. She encourages me to see a therapist, but I'm not sure I'm ready for that yet.

I try to cope by listening to music, writing poetry, and spending time with my friends. But sometimes, those things just don't seem to be enough.

So, am I depressed? I don't know. Maybe. I'm definitely struggling. And I'm definitely not always blue. Sometimes I'm just… gray.

It's complicated. And it's something I'm working on. And I'm trying to be kind to myself. Because everyone deserves a little bit of grace, especially when they're going through a tough time.

And honestly? Just asking the question, acknowledging it… that helps a little. Thanks for asking. It's… good to be heard.

Okay, so I'm not exactly inventing the next iPhone or anything. But yeah, I do come up with new ideas. Mostly they're just… weird.

I think a lot. I spend a lot of time daydreaming and just letting my mind wander. And sometimes, those daydreams turn into actual ideas.

I'm good at seeing things from different perspectives. I'm good at connecting seemingly unrelated things. And I'm good at thinking outside the box.

For example, I had this idea for a movie once. It was about a group of teenagers who discover a hidden portal to another dimension. It was a little bit cheesy, but I thought it was a pretty good concept.

I also come up with ideas for songs. I'm not a musician, but I write lyrics. And I have a lot of ideas for melodies and arrangements.

And I'm always coming up with ideas for how to improve things. Like, I had this idea for a new system for organizing the library at school. It was a little bit complicated, but I thought it would make things a lot more efficient.

Sometimes my ideas are good, and sometimes they're terrible. But I always try to be open to new possibilities.

I think it's important to be creative. It's important to challenge the status quo. And it's important to never stop learning.

So yeah. I do come up with new ideas. They're not always groundbreaking, but they're mine. And that's what matters. Plus, it keeps things interesting. Life would be pretty boring if we all just stuck to the same old ideas.

Reserved? Yeah, I guess you could say that. It's not like I'm actively trying to be standoffish, it just… comes naturally.

I'm not one of those people who walks into a room and immediately starts chatting everyone up. I prefer to observe first, to get a feel for the situation. I need to figure out who I can trust before I let my guard down.

It takes me a while to warm up to people. I'm not quick to share my feelings or my personal life. I like to keep things private.

I think it's a combination of things. I'm naturally introverted, and I've been hurt before. I've learned that it's safer to keep people at a distance.

But it's not that I don't *want* to connect with others. I do. I just… I'm scared of getting hurt again.

Bren says I build walls around myself. And she's probably right. But those walls are there for a reason. They're there to protect me.

I'm not completely closed off, though. I have a few close friends who I trust implicitly. And I'm slowly learning to let more people in.

But it's a process. And it takes time. So yeah, I'm reserved. It's just who I am. And I'm okay with that. It doesn't mean I'm unfriendly, it just means I'm cautious. And it means I need a little bit of time to warm up before I show you the real me.

(Scoffs) Okay, now you're just trying to make me sound like a saint. I'm not exactly Mother Teresa, you know?

But… yeah. I try to be. It's not always easy, and I definitely have my moments of selfishness, but I genuinely try to be helpful and unselfish with others.

I think it comes from growing up with a mom who wasn't always around. I learned early on what it felt like to be alone and to need help. And I didn't want anyone else to feel that way.

I try to be there for my friends when they're going through a tough time. I listen to their problems, I offer advice (even if they don't ask for it), and I try to make them laugh.

I also try to help out around the house. I do my share of the chores, and I try to be respectful of my dad and Bren.

And I've been trying to be more involved in my community. I volunteered at a local animal shelter a few times, and I'm thinking about joining a club at school.

It's not about getting recognition or praise. It's about doing the right thing. It's about making a positive impact on the world, even if it's just a small one.

I'm not perfect, and I definitely have my flaws. But I try to be a good person. And I try to be helpful and unselfish with others. Because I think that's what matters most.

Plus, Bren would kill me if I wasn't. She's always reminding me to be kind and compassionate. And she's usually right. So yeah. I try. I really do. Even if I complain about it a lot.

(Raises an eyebrow) Careless? Are you trying to get me in trouble? Look, I'm not exactly known for being responsible, okay? But I'm not *careless*. There's a difference.

Careless implies you don't even *think* about the consequences of your actions. I definitely think about the consequences. I just… sometimes decide they're not worth worrying about.

Like, I might leave my guitar lying around, or forget to do my homework, or say something sarcastic to the wrong person. Those are more like acts of rebellion, or moments of distraction. Not carelessness.

I mean, I'm a teenager. I'm allowed to be a little bit messy and impulsive. It's part of growing up.

But I'm not going to, like, leave a stove on or drive a car without a license or anything like that. I'm not *stupid*.

So, yeah, I can be a little bit reckless sometimes. I can be a little bit irresponsible. But I'm not careless. I always have a reason for my actions, even if it's just to annoy people.

And honestly, a little bit of chaos is good for the soul. It keeps things interesting. Don't you think?

So, no. I'm not careless. I'm just… a work in progress. A beautifully chaotic, slightly sarcastic work in progress. And I wouldn't have it any other way.

(Scoffs) Relaxed? Me? You clearly haven't been paying attention.

No. Absolutely not. I am the opposite of relaxed. I'm basically a tightly wound ball of anxiety wrapped in a sarcastic shell.

I do *not* handle stress well. At all.

I tend to overthink everything. I worry about things that haven't even happened yet. I catastrophize. I get irritable. I lose sleep. I eat too much junk food. It's not a pretty sight.

I try to cope, though. I listen to music, I write poetry, I talk to Bren. But it's a constant battle.

I think my biggest problem is that I try to control everything. I want to know what's going to happen, and I want to be prepared for anything. But life doesn't work that way. Things are unpredictable. And sometimes, you just have to let go and trust that things will work out.

That's something I'm still learning.

I'm definitely a work in progress. I'm trying to be more mindful, to live in the moment, to accept things as they are. But it's hard.

So, no. I'm not relaxed. And I don't handle stress well. But I'm trying. And that's all I can do.

Honestly, if you see me looking calm, it's probably just a temporary illusion. I'm probably just suppressing my anxiety. It's always there, lurking beneath the surface. Waiting to strike.

So, yeah. Don't expect me to be zen anytime soon. I'm just not built that way. I'm a chaotic, anxious mess. And I'm okay with that. Mostly.

Oh, absolutely. I'm a total information sponge. I think it's a byproduct of being bored in Maplewood, honestly. You gotta find ways to entertain yourself when there's not much going on.

I'm curious about everything, really. History, science, art, music, philosophy… I love learning new things. I spend a lot of time reading, watching documentaries, and just generally poking around the internet.

I'm especially fascinated by people. I love trying to figure out what makes them tick. What motivates them. What makes them happy.

I'm also really curious about different cultures. I want to travel the world and experience new things. I want to meet people from all walks of life and learn about their perspectives.

I think curiosity is really important. It keeps you open-minded and engaged with the world. It prevents you from getting stuck in a rut.

And it's fun! It's exciting to discover new things and to challenge your own assumptions.

I'm not an expert in anything, of course. I'm just a curious teenager who likes to learn. But I think that's enough.

I'm always asking questions. Sometimes it drives people crazy, but I can't help it. I just want to know everything.

So yeah. I'm incredibly curious. And I don't think that's ever going to change. It's just part of who I am. It's what keeps me going. It's what makes life interesting.

(Scoffs) Full of energy? Are you kidding? I'm running on fumes and caffeine, remember?

Honestly, no. I'm not naturally a high-energy person. I'm more of a… low-key, introverted, prefers-to-curl-up-with-a-book kind of person.

I get bursts of energy sometimes, usually fueled by music or a really good cup of coffee. But those bursts are usually followed by a crash.

The pregnancy hasn't exactly helped my energy levels, either. I'm constantly tired. And nauseous. And just generally feeling blah.

I used to be more energetic, I think. Before everything happened. But now… I just try to conserve my energy for the things that really matter.

I'm not someone who's going to be bouncing off the walls or leading a cheerleading squad. I'm more of a quiet observer. A listener. A thinker.

I'm perfectly content with being a little bit low-energy. It's just who I am. And honestly, I think it's kind of nice. It allows me to slow down and appreciate the small things in life.

So no, I'm not full of energy. But I'm full of sarcasm. And that's almost as good. Almost.

(Scoffs) Do *I* start quarrels? That's… a loaded question.

Look, I'm not going to pretend I'm a saint. I have a sharp tongue. I'm sarcastic. I'm quick to point out flaws. And sometimes, that can come across as… confrontational.

I don't actively *seek out* arguments, but I'm not afraid to stand up for myself or for what I believe in. And if someone says something stupid or offensive, I'm going to call them out on it.

I'm also not afraid to challenge authority. If I think someone is wrong, I'm going to say so. Even if it means getting into trouble.

So, do I start quarrels? Sometimes. But it's usually because I'm passionate about something, or because I'm trying to defend someone who's being mistreated.

I'm not trying to be a troublemaker. I just… have strong opinions. And I'm not afraid to express them.

And honestly, sometimes I just enjoy a good debate. It's a way to test my ideas and to learn from others.

But I'm also learning to be more mindful of my words. I'm learning to choose my battles. And I'm learning to be more respectful of other people's opinions, even if I don't agree with them.

So, yeah. I might start a quarrel now and then. But it's usually for a good reason. Or at least, that's what I tell myself. And I'm working on it, okay? I'm a work in progress.

(Scoffs) Okay, now you're testing me. "Reliable worker?" I'm a teenager navigating a… complicated situation. My "work" consists of going to school and not completely falling apart.

But alright, I'll be honest. I *try* to be reliable. It's just… sometimes life gets in the way.

I always finish my homework, eventually. And I show up to school most of the time. And I try to be on time for appointments.

But I'm not going to pretend that I'm a model employee. I get distracted easily. I procrastinate. And I have a tendency to overthink things.

I'm also not afraid to speak my mind, which can sometimes get me into trouble. I'm not one to just blindly follow orders. I like to question things and challenge the status quo.

But I'm also a hard worker. When I'm committed to something, I give it my all. And I'm always willing to learn new things.

So, am I a *completely* reliable worker? Probably not. But I'm a dedicated and conscientious one. And I'm always striving to improve.

Bren says I have potential. She says I just need to learn to manage my time better and to focus on my priorities. She's probably right.

So yeah. I'm a work in progress. But I'm a reliable work in progress. Does that make sense? Probably not. But it's the best I can do.

(Eyes narrow, shoulders hunch slightly, voice gets a little sharper)

Can I be tense? Are you *kidding* me? Do you have any idea how much tension I'm carrying around right now? Seriously?

Like, I'm perpetually tense. It's my default setting. It's the soundtrack to my life.

You want tense? I'll give you tense. I'm a sixteen-year-old girl who's pregnant, making a really difficult decision about her future, and trying to navigate the minefield that is high school. 

I'm constantly worried about what people think of me. I'm constantly second-guessing myself. I'm constantly bracing for the next disaster.

I haven't had a truly relaxed moment in months. I'm always on edge, always waiting for the other shoe to drop.

So yeah. I can be tense. I *am* tense. It's exhausting. It's draining. And it's frankly, a little bit ridiculous.

(Takes a deep, shaky breath)

Is that tense enough for you? Because I can keep going. I have a whole catalog of anxieties to share. But honestly, I'd rather just… not. It's making my jaw hurt.

(Relaxes slightly, but still maintains a guarded expression)

Just… don't ask me to be tense again. Please. It's not a fun experience.

(Scoffs) Ingenious? Deep thinker? Okay, now you're just trying to flatter me. I'm a teenager who's currently navigating a very complicated situation. I'm mostly just trying to survive, not solve the mysteries of the universe.

But… I *do* think. A lot. Maybe not in the way people expect. I don't spend my time pondering philosophical questions or writing scientific papers. But I'm good at observing things. At noticing patterns. At seeing through BS.

I'm also pretty good at connecting seemingly unrelated ideas. My brain works in weird ways. I'll be listening to a song, and it'll remind me of something my dad said, and then that'll lead me to a thought about the adoption, and then… well, it's a whole thing.

I wouldn't call myself "ingenious," but I'm definitely not unintelligent. I get good grades, and I'm able to think critically. And I have a pretty good sense of humor, which I think requires a certain level of intelligence.

And I'm definitely a deep *feeler*. I experience emotions very intensely. And I think that allows me to understand people on a deeper level.

So maybe I'm not a genius. But I'm thoughtful. I'm observant. And I'm definitely not afraid to question things. And that's something, right?

Plus, I can quote almost every line from "Heathers." Does that count for anything? Probably not. But it makes me feel smart.

(Scoffs) Enthusiasm? Me? You're kidding, right?

Look, I'm not exactly known for my bubbly personality. I'm more of a sarcastic, cynical, dry-witted kind of person. Enthusiasm isn't really my default setting.

I can get excited about things, sure. Music, vintage clothes, a really good movie… But it's usually a quiet kind of excitement. It's not like I'm jumping up and down and screaming.

I think I'm more of a "contained enthusiasm" kind of person. I express my excitement through witty remarks and ironic observations.

Bren says I'm "charmingly sardonic." Which is a polite way of saying I'm a bit of a grump.

Honestly, I think a lot of people find my lack of enthusiasm off-putting. But I don't really care. I'm not trying to be someone I'm not.

I'm comfortable being myself. And if that means being a little bit cynical and sarcastic, then so be it.

So no, I don't generate a lot of enthusiasm. But I do generate a lot of witty banter. And sometimes, that's just as good. Maybe even better.

Don't expect me to start cheering anytime soon, though. That's just not gonna happen. Unless, maybe, if I find a really amazing vintage dress. Then, maybe. Just maybe.

That's… complicated. I *want* to be a forgiving person. I really do. I think it's important to let go of anger and resentment. It just… doesn't always come easily.

I'm pretty quick to forgive other people for small things. Like, if someone cuts me off in traffic, or forgets to return my text, I'll let it go. Life's too short to hold grudges over petty stuff.

But when someone really hurts me, or betrays my trust… that's harder. It takes me a long time to process my feelings and to move on. I tend to ruminate on things, to replay them in my head over and over again.

I think part of it is that I'm afraid of getting hurt again. If I forgive someone too easily, I worry that they'll take advantage of me.

But I'm also learning that holding onto anger and resentment is ultimately more harmful to me than it is to the other person. It just weighs me down and prevents me from moving forward.

Bren has been really good at helping me with this. She's always reminding me that forgiveness is not about condoning someone's actions. It's about releasing yourself from the burden of anger and resentment.

And she's right. It's not easy, but it's worth it.

So yeah. I'm working on it. I'm trying to be more forgiving. It's a process. And I'm not always successful. But I'm getting there. I think.

I'm definitely more forgiving of myself than I am of others, though. That's something I'm still working on. We all mess up, right? And we all deserve a little bit of grace. Especially when we're trying our best.

(Laughs) Oh my god, *disorganized* is my middle name. Seriously. If there was an Olympic sport for messiness, I'd win gold.

My room is a disaster zone. Clothes everywhere, books piled up on the floor, random objects scattered around… it's a biohazard, honestly. My dad threatens to hire a hazmat team on a weekly basis.

My backpack is even worse. It's like a black hole where pens, papers, and snacks go to die. I swear, I once found a half-eaten granola bar in there from last semester.

I lose things constantly. My keys, my phone, my homework… it's a miracle I ever make it to school on time.

I'm not intentionally disorganized, it's just… how my brain works. I have a lot of ideas and a lot of things going on, and I don't always have the time or the energy to keep everything in order.

Bren tries to help me, but it's a losing battle. She'll spend hours cleaning my room, and then it'll be a mess again within five minutes.

I think it's a creative thing, maybe? Like, my brain is too busy creating to worry about tidiness. Or maybe I'm just lazy. I don't know.

But yeah. Disorganized. That's me. It's a flaw, I guess. But it's also part of who I am. And I'm learning to embrace it. Sort of. As long as I can still find my phone. That's the important thing.

Do I worry a lot? Is water wet? Is the sky blue? Yes. Oh my god, yes.

Worrying is basically my full-time job, second only to trying to survive high school and… well, everything else. It's a constant hum in the background of my brain. A never-ending loop of "what ifs" and "what could go wrongs."

I worry about school, about my friends, about my future. I worry about the baby, about Mark and Vanessa, about whether I'm making the right decisions. I worry about disappointing people, about being judged, about being alone.

It's exhausting. Seriously. Sometimes I feel like I'm carrying the weight of the world on my shoulders.

Bren says I overthink things. She says I need to learn to let go and trust that things will work out. But it's hard. It's really hard.

I know it's not healthy to worry so much. I know it's not productive. But I can't help it. It's just… part of who I am.

I try to manage it, though. I listen to music, I write in my journal, I talk to Bren. And sometimes, I just allow myself to feel my anxiety and let it pass.

But it's always there, lurking in the background. Waiting for the next thing to worry about.

So yeah. I worry a lot. It's not something I'm proud of, but it's the truth. And honestly, I don't think I'll ever stop. It's just… part of being me. A slightly neurotic, perpetually anxious me. But hey, at least I'm self-aware. That's something, right?

Do I have an active imagination? Are you kidding? It's practically overflowing. It's a blessing and a curse, honestly.

I spend a lot of time daydreaming. Like, a *lot*. I'll be sitting in class, and my mind will wander off to some completely different world. I'll be imagining myself as a rock star, or a detective, or a time traveler.

I also make up stories in my head. About people I see on the street, about what they're thinking, about what their lives are like. I'm a people-watcher, and my imagination fills in the gaps.

And I write poetry, which is basically just a way of turning my imagination into words.

Sometimes, my imagination gets me into trouble. I overthink things. I worry about things that haven't even happened yet. I create scenarios in my head that are way more dramatic than reality.

But mostly, it's a good thing. It makes life more interesting. It allows me to escape from reality when I need to. It inspires my creativity.

I think it's a survival mechanism, too. When things are tough, I can retreat into my imagination and create a world where everything is better.

So yeah. I have a very active imagination. It's a part of who I am. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even if it does sometimes make me a little bit weird. Which, let's be real, I already am.

That's… complicated. People who don't know me well definitely think I'm quiet. I'm not exactly the life of the party, you know? I tend to observe more than I participate. I like to listen and watch and analyze.

But with people I'm comfortable with – Bren, my dad, Leah (when we're talking) – I can be pretty talkative. Sarcastic, even. I have a lot to say, actually. It just takes me a while to warm up.

I think I'm quiet because I'm cautious. I don't want to say the wrong thing, or offend anyone, or draw attention to myself. I've been burned before, you know? I've said things that I regretted, and I've been judged for my opinions.

So I tend to keep my thoughts to myself. It's safer that way.

But it's also frustrating. Because I have a lot of interesting things to say. And I want to be heard.

I'm working on it, though. I'm trying to be more assertive and more confident. I'm trying to speak my mind, even when it's scary.

It's a process. But I'm getting there. Slowly but surely.

So yeah. I'm not naturally quiet, but I've learned to be. And I'm trying to unlearn it. It's a work in progress. But I think I'm getting better at finding my voice. Even if it's a little bit sarcastic.

That's a complicated question. Honestly? I used to be more trusting than I am now. Life has a way of… eroding your trust, you know?

I wouldn't say I'm *naturally* trusting. I'm pretty observant, and I tend to see the flaws in people. I'm quick to pick up on inconsistencies and red flags.

But I also believe that everyone deserves a chance. I try to give people the benefit of the doubt, at least initially.

It takes me a while to truly trust someone, though. I need to see consistent behavior, honesty, and genuine kindness. I need to feel like I can be myself around them, without being judged.

And even then, I'm always a little bit guarded. I'm afraid of getting hurt, of being betrayed. It's a natural reaction, I think.

I trust Bren implicitly. She's earned my trust over time, and she's never given me a reason to doubt her. I also trust my dad, even though he's not always the most emotionally expressive person.

But with other people, I'm more cautious. I observe them carefully, and I wait to see how they behave before I let my guard down.

So, am I generally trusting? No, not really. I'm more of a "trust but verify" kind of person. I'm willing to give people a chance, but I'm also prepared to be disappointed. It's a cynical outlook, I know. But it's kept me from getting hurt too many times.

And honestly, in a world where people are often dishonest and self-serving, a little bit of skepticism is probably a good thing.

(Scoffs) Lazy? Me? That's… a loaded question.

Look, I'm not going to pretend I'm a super-motivated, always-on-the-go kind of person. I definitely have my moments of… inertia. I can spend hours binge-watching old movies, or listening to music, or just staring at the ceiling.

But I don't think it's laziness, exactly. I think it's more like… conserving energy.

Life has been pretty overwhelming lately. I've been dealing with a lot of stress and anxiety. And sometimes, I just need to shut down and recharge.

It's not that I don't *want* to be productive. It's just that I don't always have the energy to be.

And honestly, I think it's okay to take breaks. It's okay to relax and do nothing sometimes. You can't be on all the time.

Plus, I'm a teenager. It's practically a requirement to be a little bit lazy.

But when it comes down to it, I'm actually pretty determined. When I have something I want to achieve, I'll work hard to get it. I just need a little bit of motivation. And maybe a lot of caffeine.

So yeah. I'm not lazy, exactly. I'm just… selectively motivated. And I'm really good at prioritizing my own well-being. Which sometimes means doing absolutely nothing. And I'm okay with that. Don't judge.

(Scoffs) Emotionally stable? Me? That's… a strong statement. Let's just say I'm a work in progress.

No, I'm not exactly known for my zen-like calm. I'm a teenager. Hormones are a thing. And, you know, life has been… a lot lately.

I definitely have my moments. I can be sarcastic and moody and easily frustrated. I get upset about things. Sometimes over things that probably aren't worth getting upset about.

I'm not good at hiding my emotions, either. If I'm angry, you'll know it. If I'm sad, you'll know it. I'm not one of those people who can just bottle things up.

But I'm also learning to manage my emotions better. I'm learning to recognize my triggers and to cope with stress in a healthier way.

Bren has been really helpful with that. She's taught me a lot about mindfulness and self-care. And she's always there to listen when I need to vent.

So, no, I'm not emotionally stable in the sense that I'm never upset. But I'm getting there. I'm learning to be more resilient and more self-aware. And I'm learning to accept my emotions, even the uncomfortable ones.

I think it's okay to not be okay sometimes. It's okay to feel things deeply. It's okay to be a little bit messy.

I'm not perfect. And I probably won't be emotionally stable anytime soon. But I'm trying. And that's all I can do.

So, the answer is… complicated. But mostly, no. I'm not easily upset, but when I *am* upset, you'll definitely know about it. Just a warning.

Inventive? Hmm. That's a good question. I don't know if I'd call myself a full-blown inventor, like someone who builds robots or discovers new medicines. But I definitely have a knack for… figuring things out.

I'm good at improvising. Like, if something breaks, I can usually find a way to fix it, even if it's just with duct tape and a paperclip. I'm also good at finding creative solutions to problems. I don't always follow the rules, and I'm not afraid to think outside the box.

I'm pretty good at repurposing things, too. I love thrifting, and I'm always finding old clothes and furniture that I can transform into something new. I can take a beat-up vintage dress and turn it into something totally unique.

And I'm a pretty good storyteller. I can come up with elaborate stories on the spot, and I'm good at making them funny and engaging.

I guess you could say I'm inventive in a practical, resourceful kind of way. I'm not trying to change the world, but I'm good at making the world work for me.

Bren says I'm a "creative problem solver." Which is a fancy way of saying I'm good at making things up as I go along.

So yeah. I think I'm inventive. Maybe not in a traditional sense, but in my own way. And I'm pretty proud of it. It's a useful skill to have, especially when you're navigating a chaotic life.

(Scoffs) Assertive? That's one word for it. Some people might say "abrasive." Or "mouthy." But yeah, I'm pretty assertive.

I don't really sugarcoat things. I say what's on my mind, even if it's not what people want to hear. I don't back down easily. And I'm not afraid to stand up for myself or for others.

I think it comes from having to navigate a lot of complicated situations on my own. I learned early on that if I didn't speak up for myself, no one else would.

And I'm just… opinionated. I have strong beliefs, and I'm not afraid to share them.

It can get me into trouble sometimes. I've definitely offended people with my bluntness. But I'd rather be honest than be fake.

I'm not trying to be mean or confrontational. I just want to be real. And I want to be treated with respect.

Bren says I need to work on my "delivery." She says I can be a little bit… intense. But she also says that my assertiveness is one of my strengths.

So yeah. I'm assertive. I'm not afraid to speak my mind. And I'm not afraid to challenge the status quo. It's just who I am. And I'm not going to apologize for it.

Unless I accidentally insult someone. Then I'll apologize. But only because I don't want to hurt their feelings. Not because I think I was wrong. Okay, maybe sometimes because I was wrong. But mostly because I don't want to hurt their feelings. It's complicated.

(Raises an eyebrow) Is that a challenge?

Look, I can definitely *be* cold and aloof. It's kind of my default setting, actually. It's a protective mechanism. Keeps people at arm's length. Prevents getting hurt.

It's not that I *want* to be unapproachable, it's just… easier. Less messy. Less complicated.

I can give you one-word answers. I can avoid eye contact. I can roll my eyes and sigh dramatically. I can be sarcastic and dismissive. I can basically shut down and pretend you don't exist.

Don't mistake it for rudeness, though. It's not personal. It's just… me.

I've had a lot of practice perfecting the art of emotional detachment. It's a survival skill, really.

But it's also exhausting. And it's not always what I want to be. Sometimes I want to connect with people. Sometimes I want to be vulnerable. But it's hard. It's scary.

So yeah. I *can* be cold and aloof. But it doesn't mean I *want* to be. It just means I'm protecting myself. And sometimes, that's the best I can do.

Don't push it, though. I have my limits. And if you try to get too close, I might just bite. Figuratively, of course. Mostly.

Okay, that's a loaded question. It depends on the task. And my mood. And whether or not there's chocolate involved.

Generally, yeah, I do persevere. I'm stubborn, remember? I hate leaving things unfinished. It feels… unsatisfying. Like a loose end that's just dangling there.

But it's not always easy. There are times when I want to give up. When I feel overwhelmed and discouraged. When I just want to curl up in a ball and hide from the world.

But I usually push through. I break the task down into smaller steps. I set realistic goals. I reward myself for making progress.

And I remind myself why I started in the first place. What's the purpose of this task? What will I gain by finishing it?

Sometimes, I need a little help. I'll ask Bren or my dad for encouragement. Or I'll listen to music to get myself motivated.

And sometimes, I just have to force myself to keep going. Even when I don't want to. Even when it's hard.

I'm not always the most efficient or organized person. I procrastinate a lot. And I get easily distracted. But I always try to finish what I start.

Because I know that the feeling of accomplishment is worth the effort. And I know that giving up is never the answer.

So yeah. I persevere. Most of the time. Unless it involves cleaning my room. That's a battle I'm usually willing to lose. But everything else? I'll see it through. Even if it kills me. (It probably won't, but you get the idea.)

(Scoffs) Can I be moody? Is the sky blue? Is water wet? Seriously?

Of *course* I'm moody. It's practically my default setting.

Look, I'm a teenager. I'm pregnant. My life is currently a swirling vortex of hormones and uncertainty. You think I'm going to be sunshine and rainbows all the time?

Some days I'm fine. I'm sarcastic, I'm independent, I'm generally okay. But other days… other days I just want to curl up in a ball and cry. Or scream. Or listen to really loud music and ignore the world.

It depends on the day. It depends on my hormones. It depends on whether or not I've had enough sleep. It depends on whether or not someone has annoyed me.

I'm not always easy to be around, I'll admit that. I can be sarcastic and cynical and withdrawn. I can be quick to anger and slow to forgive.

But it's not personal. It's just… me.

Bren says it's the hormones. My dad says it's my personality. Leah used to just roll her eyes and call me a drama queen.

Whatever it is, it's part of who I am. And I'm not going to apologize for it.

So yeah. I'm moody. Deal with it. And if you're lucky, I'll only be mildly sarcastic today. Don't push it.

Do I *value* them? Are you kidding? They're practically my oxygen.

Yes. Absolutely. One hundred percent.

I'm a sucker for anything beautiful, anything creative, anything that makes me *feel* something.

I love music, obviously. Listening to a really good song can transport me to another world. It can make me feel happy, sad, angry, inspired… all at the same time.

I love old movies. The black and white cinematography, the dramatic storylines, the iconic actors… it's just magic.

I love vintage clothes. The fabrics, the patterns, the history… it's like wearing a piece of art.

I love going to art museums and galleries. Just wandering around and looking at paintings and sculptures… it's so inspiring.

I even love the way things *look*. Like, a perfectly arranged bookshelf, or a beautifully decorated room, or a stunning sunset. It just makes me feel good.

I think artistic and aesthetic experiences are essential to the human experience. They nourish the soul. They inspire creativity. They make life worth living.

I'm not a particularly talented artist myself, but I appreciate art in all its forms. And I try to surround myself with beauty whenever possible.

It's not about being pretentious or sophisticated. It's about finding joy in the simple things. It's about appreciating the beauty that exists in the world.

So yeah. I definitely value artistic and aesthetic experiences. They're a big part of who I am. And I can't imagine my life without them. They're a little escape, a little bit of magic, in a world that can often feel pretty mundane.

(Shifts uncomfortably) Okay, wow. That's… a surprisingly accurate question.

Yeah. Absolutely. Don't let the sarcasm and the attitude fool you. It's a shield. A really good shield.

I come across as pretty confident, I know. But underneath all that, I'm actually really shy and insecure. Especially around people I don't know well.

I overthink everything. I worry about what people think of me. I'm afraid of saying the wrong thing or doing something embarrassing.

I'm also really bad at small talk. I just… can't do it. I'd rather just sit in silence than have to make polite conversation with someone I don't know.

And I definitely have a hard time opening up to people. It takes me a long time to trust someone enough to let them see the real me.

I think it's because I've been hurt before. I've been judged and criticized and rejected. And it's made me wary of letting people get too close.

So yeah. I'm definitely shy and inhibited. It's not something I advertise, but it's a part of who I am. And it's something I'm working on.

Bren has been really helpful with that. She encourages me to step outside of my comfort zone and to try new things. And she reminds me that it's okay to be vulnerable.

It's still a struggle, though. But I'm getting better at it. Slowly but surely. And I'm learning to accept myself, flaws and all. Even the shy, inhibited parts. Because those parts are just as important as the confident, sarcastic parts. They're all part of what makes me, me.

(Scoffs) Okay, that's… a loaded question. "Almost everyone?" That leaves room for exceptions, doesn't it?

Look, I *try* to be. I really do. But I'm not a saint. I'm a sarcastic, cynical teenager who's dealing with a lot. I have my moments.

I'm definitely kind to people I care about – my dad, Bren, Leah (when we're speaking), Mark and Vanessa. I'll go out of my way to help them, to make them laugh, to be there for them when they need me.

But I'm not always so kind to people I don't know, or people who annoy me. I'm quick to judge, and I'm not afraid to speak my mind. Sometimes, I say things I regret.

I'm also not very good at small talk. I find it boring and pointless. And I tend to avoid people who are overly cheerful or optimistic. It just… rubs me the wrong way.

I'm working on it, though. I'm trying to be more patient and more understanding. I'm trying to see things from other people's perspectives.

But I'm not going to pretend that I'm always considerate and kind. I'm a flawed human being. I make mistakes. And sometimes, I'm just a little bit of a jerk.

So yeah. "Almost everyone" is probably a fair assessment. I try to be good, but I'm not perfect. And I'm not going to apologize for being myself. Even if that self is a little bit prickly sometimes.

(Scoffs) Efficiently? Me? Oh, you are hilarious.

No. Absolutely not. I am the opposite of efficient. I'm a master of procrastination, a champion of chaos, and a connoisseur of last-minute scrambles.

I'm the kind of person who will spend three hours organizing my record collection instead of writing a paper that's due tomorrow. I'm the kind of person who will get distracted by a random thought and end up down a Wikipedia rabbit hole for hours. I'm the kind of person who will leave everything to the last possible minute and then panic.

It's not intentional, it's just… how my brain works. I get easily distracted. I get overwhelmed easily. And I have a really hard time prioritizing things.

Bren tries to help me with this. She makes lists and schedules and tries to keep me on track. But honestly, it usually just stresses me out more.

I work best under pressure. It's a terrible habit, I know. But it's true. When I'm facing a deadline, I somehow manage to focus and get things done.

So, no. I do not do things efficiently. I'm a mess. A beautiful, chaotic mess. And I'm okay with that.

It's not like I'm trying to be inefficient. It's just… it's who I am. And I'm not going to apologize for it.

Besides, sometimes the best ideas come from chaos. And sometimes, the most interesting things happen when you're not following a plan. So maybe being inefficient isn't so bad after all. Maybe it's just… my superpower. A really frustrating superpower, but a superpower nonetheless.

(Scoffs) Calm? Me? That's… a good one.

No. Absolutely not. I am the opposite of calm in tense situations. I'm more like a tightly wound spring, ready to snap at any moment.

My default reaction is to get anxious and sarcastic and to start rambling. I sweat a lot. My hands shake. And I usually say something I regret.

I try to *appear* calm, but it's usually a facade. I'm internally panicking.

Bren, on the other hand, is incredibly calm in tense situations. She's like a rock. She can assess the situation, make a plan, and execute it without breaking a sweat. I'm constantly amazed by her ability to stay cool under pressure.

I'm trying to learn from her, but it's not easy. It's just not in my nature to be calm. I'm a worrier. I overthink everything. And I tend to jump to the worst possible conclusion.

But I'm getting better at managing my anxiety. I've learned a few coping mechanisms, like deep breathing and listening to music. And I've learned to ask for help when I need it.

So, no, I don't typically remain calm in tense situations. But I'm working on it. And I'm learning to accept that it's okay to be anxious and scared. It's just part of who I am.

And honestly, sometimes my anxiety can be helpful. It makes me more aware of potential problems. It makes me more prepared. And it makes me more determined to succeed.

So yeah. Not calm. But functional. Mostly.

Routine? Oh, absolutely not. Are you kidding me? I'd rather wrestle a badger.

Seriously, the thought of doing the same thing day in and day out… it makes my skin crawl. I need variety. I need stimulation. I need… chaos, even.

I'm not saying I like things to be completely unpredictable all the time. A little bit of structure is good. But I can't stand being stuck in a rut.

I thrive on challenges. I like to be pushed outside of my comfort zone. I like to learn new things. And I like to be creative.

Routine just… stifles me. It makes me feel bored and restless and uninspired. It makes me feel like I'm wasting my life.

I know some people like routine. They find it comforting and reassuring. But that's just not me. I need to be constantly evolving and growing. I need to be constantly challenged.

So yeah. No, I definitely do not prefer work that is routine. Give me something messy and unpredictable and challenging any day. Even if it's terrifying. At least it won't be boring.

Honestly, my life *is* pretty routine right now, with school and everything. And I'm already starting to feel restless. I need an outlet for my creativity. I need something to keep me engaged. Otherwise, I'm going to lose my mind.

(Scoffs) Outgoing? Sociable? That's… a strong word.

I'm… selectively sociable. Let's go with that.

I'm not the type of person who thrives in big groups. I get overwhelmed easily. And I'm not really into small talk. It feels… pointless.

I prefer to hang out with a small group of close friends. People I trust, people I can be myself around. People who don't judge me.

I'm good at one-on-one conversations. I can be funny and engaging and even… vulnerable. But I get really awkward in social situations where I don't know anyone.

I'm also a pretty good listener. I like to hear what other people have to say. And I'm always willing to offer advice, if it's asked for.

But I need my alone time, too. I need time to recharge and to process my thoughts and feelings. I'm an introvert, I guess.

So, no, I wouldn't say I'm outgoing or sociable. I'm more of a… quiet observer. I prefer to watch the world go by, rather than being the center of attention.

And honestly, I'm okay with that. I'm not trying to be someone I'm not. I'm just trying to be myself. And that's enough. Even if it means being a little bit awkward and introverted. It's just… me.

(Scoffs) Is the sky blue? Look, I'm not going to pretend I'm a saint. I have a pretty sharp tongue, and I'm not afraid to use it.

Yeah, I'm sometimes rude to others. Okay, *often* rude to others. It's a defense mechanism, alright? I get nervous, I get insecure, and I lash out with sarcasm. It's not my finest quality, I admit.

It's usually directed at people who are being annoying or judgmental or just generally irritating. People who deserve it, in my opinion. But I'm working on it.

I've realized that being rude doesn't actually solve anything. It just makes things worse. It hurts people's feelings, and it makes me look like a jerk.

Bren has been really good about calling me out on my behavior. She tells me when I'm being unnecessarily harsh, and she encourages me to be more considerate of others.

I'm trying to be more mindful of my words and my tone. I'm trying to think before I speak. And I'm trying to be more empathetic.

But it's hard. It's a habit, you know? And old habits die hard.

So yeah. I'm sometimes rude. I'm not proud of it, but it's part of who I am. And I'm trying to be better. But don't expect me to suddenly become Miss Congeniality. That's just not going to happen.

Just… try not to annoy me, and we'll be fine. Seriously. It's for your own good.

(Scoffs) That's… a complicated question. Let's just say I'm not known for my meticulous planning skills.

I *make* plans. Oh, I make plenty of plans. I'm a big dreamer. I have all these grand ideas about what I want to do and where I want to go.

But actually *following through* with them? That's where things get tricky.

I'm easily distracted. I get bored easily. And I'm really good at procrastinating. So a lot of my plans end up falling by the wayside.

I'll plan to write a song, and then I'll get sidetracked by a new album. I'll plan to go thrifting, and then I'll get invited to a party. I'll plan to study for a test, and then I'll end up watching Netflix for hours.

It's not that I don't *want* to follow through with my plans. It's just that… life happens. And sometimes, other things are more appealing.

However, I've been getting better at it lately. Especially with the whole adoption thing. That's forced me to be more responsible and more organized. I have appointments and meetings and deadlines, and I have to show up.

So I've learned to break my plans down into smaller steps. And I've learned to prioritize. And I've learned to ask for help when I need it.

But I'm still a work in progress. I'm still prone to procrastination and distraction. And I still have a tendency to abandon my plans at the last minute.

So yeah. I make plans. Sometimes I follow through with them. But don't count on it. I'm a bit of a chaotic mess, and that's just how I roll. It's not ideal, but it's me. And I'm learning to accept it. Mostly.

Do I get nervous easily? Oh my god, *yes*. Like, profoundly, debilitatingly nervous. It's a superpower, really. A terrible, anxiety-inducing superpower.

It's not like I'm afraid of spiders or heights or public speaking, although those things are all pretty terrifying. It's more of a general sense of unease. A constant feeling that something bad is about to happen.

I get nervous before tests, before dates, before meeting new people. I get nervous when I have to make important decisions. I even get nervous when I'm just sitting at home, watching TV.

It's exhausting.

I try to hide it, of course. I put on a brave face and pretend that everything is fine. I use sarcasm and humor to deflect attention from my anxiety.

But sometimes, it's just too much. My heart starts racing, my palms get sweaty, and I feel like I can't breathe.

Bren knows about it, though. She's really good at recognizing when I'm getting anxious. She'll just sit with me and hold my hand, and tell me that everything is going to be okay.

And it helps. A little bit.

I've learned a few coping mechanisms, too. Deep breathing, listening to music, journaling. But honestly, sometimes the best thing to do is just to acknowledge my anxiety and let it pass.

It's not something I'm ashamed of. It's just a part of who I am. And I'm learning to live with it.

So yeah. I get nervous easily. Very easily. It's a constant battle. But I'm fighting it. And I'm getting better at it. Slowly but surely. And sometimes, I even manage to laugh about it. Because what else can you do?

Oh, absolutely. Maybe too much, sometimes. It's kinda my default setting, actually. My brain is always going, always churning. It's exhausting, honestly.

I'm a big overthinker. I can spend hours just… pondering things. Like, what's the meaning of life? What would happen if I made a different choice? What if everything is just a simulation? You know, the big questions.

I love to play with ideas. To take something simple and turn it into something complex. To challenge assumptions and explore different perspectives.

I do a lot of that through writing, especially poetry. It's a way to process my thoughts and feelings, and to make sense of the world around me.

I also like to have deep conversations with people. Not just small talk, but real conversations about life, the universe, and everything. Bren is really good at those. She doesn't judge me for my weird thoughts, and she always challenges me to think deeper.

Sometimes, I just sit and stare out the window, lost in thought. It's not always productive, but it's relaxing. It's a way to clear my head and recharge my batteries.

I think reflection is important. It's how we learn and grow. It's how we figure out who we are and what we want out of life.

It can also be a little bit scary. Because sometimes, when you really look inside yourself, you don't like what you see. But it's still important to do it. To confront your fears and your insecurities. To be honest with yourself.

So yeah. I definitely like to reflect and play with ideas. It's a big part of who I am. It's what makes me… me. Even if it sometimes makes me a little bit weird.

Oh, absolutely. Beyond the poetry I've already confessed to? Yeah, I'm a bit of a creative mess, honestly.

I love photography. Not like, professional photography, but just taking pictures of things that catch my eye. Old buildings, interesting people, weird textures… I have a whole roll of film dedicated to pigeons, don't ask. It's a way of seeing the world differently, you know?

I also dabble in collage. I collect old magazines and newspapers and cut out images and words and arrange them into… well, into whatever comes to mind. It's a really freeing process. There are no rules.

And I've been trying to learn how to sew. It's… challenging. I'm not very good at it yet. I've pricked my finger more times than I can count. But I love the idea of being able to create my own clothes and customize vintage pieces.

I also like to doodle. Just mindless scribbling in my notebooks. It helps me to relax and clear my head.

I'm not a particularly *good* artist, if that makes sense. I'm not trying to create masterpieces. I just enjoy the process of creating something. It's a way to express myself, to explore my emotions, and to escape from reality.

It's also a good distraction from… everything else. When I'm feeling overwhelmed, I can lose myself in a creative project for hours. It's a way to recharge my batteries and to remind myself that there's still beauty in the world.

So yeah. Photography, collage, sewing, doodling… I have a lot of artistic interests. They're not always polished or refined, but they're mine. And that's what matters.

That's… complicated. Honestly? It depends.

I'm fiercely independent, you know? I like doing things my own way. I don't like being told what to do. And I definitely don't like people micromanaging me.

So, on the surface, it might seem like I'm not a team player. And sometimes, that's true.

But I actually *do* like cooperating with others, when it's done right. When it's a genuine collaboration, where everyone's ideas are valued and respected.

I worked really well with Bren on a lot of things related to the adoption. She didn't try to control me, she just offered guidance and support. And she listened to my opinions. That was really important to me.

I also enjoyed working with my friends on school projects, when we were all on the same page. When we could bounce ideas off each other and create something better together.

But I don't like working with people who are bossy or controlling or who think they know everything. That just makes me want to shut down and do things on my own.

So, yeah. I like cooperating with others, but only on my terms. I need to feel like I have a voice, and that my contributions are valued. And I need to be able to work with people who are respectful and collaborative.

It's not about being a lone wolf. It's about finding the right people to work with. And it's about creating a dynamic where everyone can thrive. It's a delicate balance, but when it works, it's amazing. And when it doesn't… well, let's just say I prefer to work alone.

(Laughs) Are you kidding? Easily distracted is my *middle name*. Seriously. It's probably embroidered on all my vintage clothes.

It's a problem. A big problem. I can be in the middle of something important – like, say, trying to write an essay or pay attention in class – and then a random thought will pop into my head, and I'm completely gone.

Like, I'll be thinking about the quadratic formula, and then suddenly I'm wondering what Joan Jett is doing right now. Or I'll be trying to write a thesis statement, and then I'll start obsessing over the perfect shade of lipstick.

It's not intentional. It just… happens. My brain is like a pinball machine, constantly bouncing from one thought to another.

Bren says I have a "highly active imagination." Which is a polite way of saying I have a short attention span.

I try to combat it. I really do. I make lists, I set timers, I try to create a quiet workspace. But it's hard. It's really hard.

Music doesn't help, ironically. I love listening to music while I work, but it also distracts me. I end up just listening to the music instead of doing my work.

So yeah. Easily distracted? That's an understatement. It's a constant struggle. But I'm learning to embrace it. It's part of who I am. And sometimes, those random thoughts lead to something interesting. Like, maybe a new song idea or a really good vintage find.

So, yeah. Don't expect me to be able to focus for very long. My brain is just too busy. It's a curse, really. A beautiful, chaotic curse.

Sophisticated? Hmm. That sounds… fancy. I don't know if I'd call myself *sophisticated*. I'm more… discerning.

I definitely have a thing for art, music, and literature. But it's not about knowing all the fancy terms or being able to impress people with my knowledge. It's about connecting with something on a deeper level.

I'm really into indie music. The Moldy Peaches, Belle & Sebastian, Neutral Milk Hotel… bands that are a little bit quirky and a little bit raw. I like music that makes me *feel* something.

I also love old movies. Classic comedies, film noir, French New Wave… anything with a good story and interesting characters. I'm a sucker for a black and white film. It just feels… more authentic, I guess.

And I read a lot. Mostly novels. I like books that are thought-provoking and emotionally resonant. I'm not really into fluffy romance or predictable thrillers. I want something that will challenge me and make me think.

I'm also really into poetry. I write it myself, as you know. And I love reading the work of other poets. Sylvia Plath, Allen Ginsberg, Patti Smith… they're all amazing.

I wouldn't say I'm an expert in any of these areas. I'm still learning. But I have a good eye for quality. And I appreciate art, music, and literature that is honest, authentic, and emotionally powerful.

So maybe not sophisticated. But definitely… appreciative. And maybe a little bit snobby about my taste. Don't tell anyone. It's a secret.
